Subject: Biology
Content: Section A: Section A

Subject: Biology
Content: Section B: Section B

Subject: Biology
Content: Location W

Subject: Biology
Content: The role of the Golgi apparatus in a cell is to receive proteins from the rough endoplasmic reticulum and modify and package them into vesicles to assist the proteins to be secreted/transported/exocytosed.

Subject: Biology
Content: Student responses needed to be specific to the role of the Golgi apparatus and not a general description of the process of exocytosis.

Subject: Biology
Content: The description of the role of tRNA in the production of a protein could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Carrying specific amino acids to the ribosome for translation

Subject: Biology
Content: That the anticodon on tRNA binds to the complementary mRNA codon

Subject: Biology
Content: Allowing amino acids to be joined together to form a polypeptide chain.

Subject: Biology
Content: An explanation of how an enzyme catalyses the breakdown of a protein could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Speeding up the rate of reaction or lowering activation energy

Subject: Biology
Content: The substrate binding to the complementary active site on the enzyme

Subject: Biology
Content: Breaking peptide bonds between amino acids.

Subject: Biology
Content: Many students simply restated the stem; statements such as 'enzymes catalyse reactions' and 'enzymes break down proteins' were not awarded marks.

Subject: Biology
Content: The description of the role of vesicles in the export of protein could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Transporting the protein to the plasma membrane

Subject: Biology
Content: Fusing with the cell membrane

Subject: Biology
Content: Carrying the protein to/from the Golgi apparatus.

Subject: Biology
Content: Many students incorrectly stated that the vesicle fuses with the cell wall.

Subject: Biology
Content: This was a challenging question assessing the key science skill of 'analyse and explain how models and theories are used to organise and understand observed phenomena and concepts related to biology, identifying limitations of selected models/theories'.

Subject: Biology
Content: Many students incorrectly outlined a limitation of protein synthesis instead of a limitation of the scientific model of protein synthesis. Other common incorrect responses included the suggestion that the contributions from different scientists meant the model was not accurate or that the model was 'open to interpretation' (confusing it with limitations of the human fossil record classification scheme).

Subject: Biology
Content: Students should be provided with opportunities throughout the course to investigate and apply key science skills such as those related to modelling as both a scientific investigation methodology and as a way of organising and understanding observed phenomena and concepts relating to biology.

Subject: Biology
Content: Students were required to provide an appropriate description of an organism's proteome: all of the proteins produced by an organism.

Subject: Biology
Content: The explanation of how organisms achieve such diversity in cell types then needed to reference both intestinal epithelial cells and fat cells, and could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: That genes code for proteins

Subject: Biology
Content: A description of gene regulation

Subject: Biology
Content: A description of alternative splicing

Subject: Biology
Content: That mutations can occur that cause a different protein to be produced

Subject: Biology
Content: That different cells produce different proteins

Subject: Biology
Content: That different proteins fold differently.

Subject: Biology
Content: High-scoring responses included a range of different explanations of how different cells can produce different proteins, making reference to both cells. Students needed to specifically refer to each of the two cells in their response to be awarded full marks. Many students did not specifically describe the proteome, as required by the question.

Subject: Biology
Content: Reasons why glucose does not reduce to zero over the 500 hours could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Fermentation / glycolysis / anaerobic respiration stopping

Subject: Biology
Content: More time required for all the glucose to be consumed

Subject: Biology
Content: Build-up of ethanol being toxic to yeast cells or altering the pH

Subject: Biology
Content: The yeast cells already meeting their ATP demands

Subject: Biology
Content: Other limiting factors (e.g. number of yeast cells, amount of coenzyme) prohibiting further breakdown.

Subject: Biology
Content: Many students included factually correct statements related to fermentation, but their response did not address what was being asked in the question.

Subject: Biology
Content: Adding oxygen would result in a decrease in ethanol being produced OR no ethanol being produced.

Subject: Biology
Content: This would be due to aerobic cellular respiration occurring OR less glucose being available for (anaerobic) fermentation OR because ethanol is only produced by (anaerobic) fermentation.

Subject: Biology
Content: Alternatively, ethanol could have continued to be produced.

Subject: Biology
Content: This would be due to (anaerobic) fermentation still occurring in the presence of oxygen.

Subject: Biology
Content: Students should note that even in the presence of oxygen, anaerobic fermentation still occurs. Reference to aerobic fermentation was incorrect because it contradicted the fact that fermentation is an anaerobic process.

Subject: Biology
Content: Explanations of why photosynthesis is considered a biochemical pathway could have included that:

Subject: Biology
Content: The outputs of one reaction are the inputs of the next reaction

Subject: Biology
Content: It involves a series of reactions (light-dependent stage and light-independent stage)

Subject: Biology
Content: It involves enzymes (e.g. Rubisco) and/or coenzymes (e.g. ADP/ATP and NADP/NADPH)

Subject: Biology
Content: It involves different reactions occurring in different locations (grana / thylakoid membrane and stroma)

Subject: Biology
Content: It is regulated by availability of reactants / concentration of products / abiotic factors.

Subject: Biology
Content: It was common for students to specifically refer to the various inputs/outputs, stages, locations, enzymes and coenzymes involved in photosynthesis. However, some students provided a more generic response about biochemical pathways, which for this examination could also be awarded full marks.

Subject: Biology
Content: To support the statement that C4 plants growing next to C3 plants had an advantage, students could have provided any three of the following:

Subject: Biology
Content: Specific use of data for both plants (e.g. at 400 lux, C3 plant carbon fixation rate is 90 mmol/hr; C4 plant carbon fixation rate is 150 mmol/hr)

Subject: Biology
Content: C4 plants fix more CO2 (at all light intensities) than C3 plants

Subject: Biology
Content: C4 plants fix CO2 at a faster/higher rate than C3 plants

Subject: Biology
Content: C4 plants have increased photosynthesis / growth / glucose production OR decreased photorespiration compared to C3 plants.

Subject: Biology
Content: High-scoring responses usually included specific data from the graph and then linked this to increased carbon fixation in C4 plants and explained how this would specifically benefit these plants. Some students incorrectly wrote about C4 plants taking up more CO2, as opposed to fixing more CO2.

Subject: Biology
Content: Students needed to answer both parts of the question to be awarded full marks. Many students addressed why CO2 fixation plateaued but not why it initially changed as light intensity increased. Some students simply stated that as light intensity increased, CO2 fixation increased, without explaining why or how. Some students incorrectly identified light as a limiting factor to explain why CO2 fixation plateaued.

Subject: Biology
Content: Explanations of how C4 plants are better adapted to reducing photorespiration compared to C3 plants could have included that:

Subject: Biology
Content: C4 plants function better at higher temperatures than C3 plants

Subject: Biology
Content: Rubisco binds less to O2 OR has a higher affinity for CO2 in C4 plants compared to C3 plants

Subject: Biology
Content: CO2 fixation occurs in bundle sheath cells in C4 plants and in mesophyll cells in C3 plants

Subject: Biology
Content: In C4 plants, CO2 enters the light-independent stage / Calvin cycle with less competition from O2 compared to C3 plants.

Subject: Biology
Content: Students were required to make a comparison between C3 and C4 plants to be awarded full marks. A common misconception was that the bundle sheath and the mesophyll were located in different areas within the same cell or within the chloroplast. Some students confused C4 plants with CAM plants and incorrectly wrote about C4 plants closing their stomata during the day to avoid photorespiration.

Subject: Biology
Content: A response had to have all boxes within the table correct to be awarded the mark. In some cases, for the total nitrogen (%) of the transformed (Hv1) plant, students wrote the incorrect value of 0.6. Students are encouraged to bring a ruler into the examination and use it to read graphs accurately.

Subject: Biology
Content: The change in either chlorophyll or nitrogen in the transformed barley plant could have impacted the plant in the following ways.

Subject: Biology
Content: Students tended to select the chlorophyll option over nitrogen, and this was easier for them to justify using their biological content knowledge. When discussing nitrogen, many students only discussed the environmental benefit of using less nitrogen fertiliser rather than the impact on the plant if more nitrogen was available. Students needed to be aware that nitrogen is a key component of nucleic acid and protein structure.

Subject: Biology
Content: Note: 'increasing the efficiency of photosynthesis' or 'improving photosynthesis' is not the same as 'increased photosynthesis'.

Subject: Biology
Content: Explanations of why some barley seeds may not have been transformed could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Not all seeds/cells incorporated the CRISPR-Cas9

Subject: Biology
Content: The gene may not always be edited OR off-target editing occurred

Subject: Biology
Content: Cas9 did not bind to the PAM sequence OR did not cut the gene

Subject: Biology
Content: Single guide RNA (sgRNA) was not complementary to the target gene OR there was a mutation in the target gene

Subject: Biology
Content: The cell repaired the cut made by Cas9 without inserting the nucleotide.

Subject: Biology
Content: It was evident that the role of different components in CRISPR-Cas9 in eukaryotic cells was not well understood by students, particularly the roles of sgRNA, Cas9 endonuclease and the PAM site. The term 'transformed' in this question was often confused with the process of 'bacterial transformation' and some students incorrectly referred to plasmids in their responses.

Subject: Biology
Content: The transformed barley plant was Hv1-C.

Subject: Biology
Content: This is because BstN1 did not cut the DNA of the transformed barley plant, resulting in a larger fragment present in the gel.

Subject: Biology
Content: Students often repeated information provided in the stem to justify their selection of the transformed barley plant (e.g. BstN1 has no recognition sites for DNA from transformed barley plants). Their justification needed to rely on reference to further biological knowledge, rather than simply stating that the banding pattern in Hv1-C did not match the control. Some students incorrectly stated that the larger fragment was due to an inserted gene in the transformed plant. However, the transformation was due to a nucleotide substitution and therefore the DNA from each plant type was the same length before exposure to BstN1.

Subject: Biology
Content: DNA fragments are separated in gel electrophoresis by:

Subject: Biology
Content: Size, as smaller DNA fragments move further/faster

Subject: Biology
Content: Movement towards the positive electrode (as DNA is negatively charged).

Subject: Biology
Content: The terms 'anode' and 'cathode', and their respective charges, were often confused by students. Other incorrect responses included that the larger the DNA fragment, the more negative the charge, and that the size of the gel pores decreases further away from the gel wells.

Subject: Biology
Content: Both trastuzumab and pertuzumab have the same variable regions as they are both complementary to, and therefore bind to, the HER2 receptor.

Subject: Biology
Content: OR

Subject: Biology
Content: Trastuzumab and pertuzumab bind to the receptor at different sites. Therefore, they are complementary to different sites and have different variable regions to each other.

Subject: Biology
Content: Students were required to refer to both monoclonal antibodies in their responses. A common incorrect response was to state that the trastuzumab variable region bound to the cell membrane and the pertuzumab variable region did not.

Subject: Biology
Content: Identification of two ways in which the monoclonal antibodies could function to help treat a person with HER2-positive breast cancer could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Binding to the receptor

Subject: Biology
Content: Blocking the receptor OR preventing cancer cells from dividing/growing OR stopping growth factor being received

Subject: Biology
Content: Carrying chemotherapy drugs / radioactive isotopes to cancer cells

Subject: Biology
Content: Only targeting cancer cells OR reducing side effects by not affecting healthy cells

Subject: Biology
Content: Opsonising/flagging cancer cells (for destruction) OR stimulating immune cells

Subject: Biology
Content: Immobilising/reducing the spread of cancer cells.

Subject: Biology
Content: Some students were only able to identify one way that monoclonal antibodies could function in breast cancer treatment. Students needed to refer specifically to the effect of monoclonal antibodies on cancer cells, not just on cancer.

Subject: Biology
Content: An action taken may have been vaccination. This would have increased herd immunity by reducing the number of available hosts, thereby limiting the transmission of measles. This would have led to a decrease in the number of reported cases.

Subject: Biology
Content: Alternatively, other actions that could have been explained included the isolation/quarantine of infected individuals and increasing the education available regarding how measles infections are transmitted. These actions would have led to less transmission of measles, reducing the number of cases.

Subject: Biology
Content: Wearing masks was not accepted as an appropriate action because the measle particles can stay airborne for many hours and (surgical) masks generally have ineffective filters. Therefore, mask wearing by the general population would not have resulted in such a rapid and prolonged decrease in the number of reported cases of measles.

Subject: Biology
Content: The potential source of the measles infection could have included an infected traveller OR an unvaccinated individual contracting/spreading measles.

Subject: Biology
Content: Two benefits of listing the public locations could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Ensuring people avoided the areas

Subject: Biology
Content: Allowing those who visited the locations to monitor for symptoms OR get tested

Subject: Biology
Content: Allowing people to isolate if they suspected they may be infected

Subject: Biology
Content: Encouraging the wearing of (hospital-grade) masks

Subject: Biology
Content: Promoting booster vaccinations.

Subject: Biology
Content: Simply stating that an individual visited a place where measles was present was not accepted as a potential source of measles. Wearing of (hospital-grade) masks was accepted here, as this action would benefit specific individuals at risk of infection within the affected public locations.

Subject: Biology
Content: Each of the two factors required was awarded one mark. The respective descriptions needed to match the factor identified by students to also be awarded a separate mark each.

Subject: Biology
Content: Antigenic drift was not accepted as a factor as this involves only gradual changes in the surface antigens, which most commonly results in a slight change to an existing pathogen, rather than the emergence of a new pathogen.

Subject: Biology
Content: Antibiotic resistance was not accepted as this only occurs due to a mutation or modification of the genome for an existing bacterial pathogen, rather than the emergence of a new pathogen.

Subject: Biology
Content: Fieldwork OR classification and identification.

Subject: Biology
Content: Evidence that suggests the two groups of E. salubris are separate species could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Different molecular homologies OR different DNA / amino acid sequences

Subject: Biology
Content: Different structural morphologies OR different appearance of leaves/trees

Subject: Biology
Content: Growth in different soil phosphorus levels

Subject: Biology
Content: A lack of interbreeding between the two groups.

Subject: Biology
Content: Students often restated information from the stem of the question without clearly indicating the specific evidence that classified the E. salubris as separate species. For example, 'thinner leaves are only found in soils with high phosphorous levels' did not provide enough evidence as to why the two E. salubris groups were separate species.

Subject: Biology
Content: Sympatric (speciation)

Subject: Biology
Content: The genetic diversity between the two groups of E. salubris may have been due to:

Subject: Biology
Content: Initial variation in alleles/phenotypes

Subject: Biology
Content: The two groups being exposed to different selection pressures (e.g. different levels of phosphorus in the soil)

Subject: Biology
Content: The thinner leaf trees having a selective advantage for growing in soils with high phosphorus levels

Subject: Biology
Content: Reduced gene flow between the two groups

Subject: Biology
Content: Separate mutations accumulating in each group

Subject: Biology
Content: Reproductive isolation (as a result of flowering time / pollination).

Subject: Biology
Content: It is important that any potential misconceptions regarding genetic changes in a population over time are addressed as part of the course. Some students incorrectly included Lamarckian statements, such as suggesting the trees adapted to high phosphorus levels in the soil. Many students provided a pre-planned speciation response, whereas the question required students to discuss what led to the genetic diversity between two already separate groups/populations. The inability to breed and produce fertile offspring was not a relevant response to this question.

Subject: Biology
Content: Non-Indigenous Australians' DNA was sequenced to act as a comparison to highlight the diversity of DNA sequences within the Indigenous Australian communities.

Subject: Biology
Content: Many responses incorrectly referenced that this would allow researchers to confirm if interbreeding occurred between Indigenous and non-Indigenous individuals.

Subject: Biology
Content: Note: The terms Aboriginal, Indigenous Australians and First Nations Australian peoples were able to be used interchangeably in responses to Question 9.

Subject: Biology
Content: The ethical principle of respect could have been applied in this study through:

Subject: Biology
Content: Valuing Indigenous beliefs / cultures / customs / Country and Place / heritage / kinship

Subject: Biology
Content: Inviting Indigenous communities to take part in the research OR Indigenous individuals consenting

Subject: Biology
Content: Following Indigenous Australians' governance and custodianship

Subject: Biology
Content: Aligning research with Indigenous ways of knowing

Subject: Biology
Content: Following ethical guidelines

Subject: Biology
Content: Ensuring research was beneficial to communities.

Subject: Biology
Content: For this question in this examination, students were able to directly quote information from the source article as part of their response.

Subject: Biology
Content: Data had to include more than just numbers as it needed to relate to the difference between individuals within a community (first row of table) compared to individuals between different communities (second row of table).

Subject: Biology
Content: Explanations of how the study has contributed to advancing the understanding of human genomic diversity or treatment of genetic disease could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: All four communities sharing a common ancestor

Subject: Biology
Content: More DNA variation being observed in Indigenous individuals than anywhere outside of Africa

Subject: Biology
Content: The knowledge that DNA mutations accumulate over time

Subject: Biology
Content: Gene flow stopping before the geographical isolation of the communities

Subject: Biology
Content: Rethinking the human migration timeline/path

Subject: Biology
Content: Identifying unknown genetic diseases

Subject: Biology
Content: Determining whether one community was more prone to genetic disease than others

Subject: Biology
Content: Providing earlier or more relevant treatment OR the discovery of new treatments

Subject: Biology
Content: Tracing the origin of genetic disease over time.

Subject: Biology
Content: Students could also have referred specifically to data provided in the source information or phylogenetic tree or made a correct comparison between specific Indigenous communities.

Subject: Biology
Content: Students who chose to discuss the advancement of the understanding of the treatment of genetic disease found it easier to reach more justifiable conclusions, and were often then awarded higher marks, compared to those who chose to discuss the advancement of the understanding of human genomic diversity.

Subject: Biology
Content: For this question in this examination, students were also able to provide one advancement for the understanding of human genomic diversity and one advancement for the understanding of the treatment of genetic disease, and subsequently be awarded full marks.

Subject: Biology
Content: Examples of suitable analysis included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Group A reported 2.5 (slightly/somewhat likely) or the lowest likelihood of getting vaccinated

Subject: Biology
Content: Group B reported 3 (somewhat likely) or the second highest / lower likelihood of getting vaccinated

Subject: Biology
Content: Group C reported 3.5 (somewhat likely/likely) or the highest likelihood of getting vaccinated

Subject: Biology
Content: Groups A and B both reported between slightly likely and somewhat likely or their average likelihood was between 2 and 3

Subject: Biology
Content: The group that received the least amount of information was the least likely to get vaccinated

Subject: Biology
Content: The group that received information on individual benefits had an increased likelihood of getting vaccinated

Subject: Biology
Content: The group that received information on herd immunity had the highest likelihood of getting vaccinated

Subject: Biology
Content: Groups that received any additional information had an increased likelihood of vaccination.

Subject: Biology
Content: This question was well answered. Common incorrect responses included students not providing sufficient detail in their analysis or linking the number on the graph to an incorrect context (e.g. 3.5 does not mean 3.5 people or 3.5%, it means 3.5 average likelihood (out of 5) of getting vaccinated).

Subject: Biology
Content: Improve education or promote/advertise information about the benefits of vaccination (such as herd immunity, population/individual benefits and preventing illness).

Subject: Biology
Content: Some students simply identified 'strategy C' or 'strategies B and C', which were also acceptable responses.

Subject: Biology
Content: Acceptable other strategies included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Free/subsidised vaccination

Subject: Biology
Content: Mandatory vaccination / school vaccination program / no jab no play

Subject: Biology
Content: Financial incentives to individuals who are vaccinated (e.g. rebates/vouchers)

Subject: Biology
Content: Restriction on travel / banned from public places (e.g. cinemas).

Subject: Biology
Content: A common incorrect response to this question was to propose a second strategy that was also linked to the student's findings from their student-designed scientific investigation, that is, a strategy that related to improving education about vaccines or promoting/advertising the benefits of vaccines. This was not awarded marks as the question specifically asked for another strategy, which therefore needed to be unrelated to the acceptable responses for Question 10b.i.

Subject: Biology
Content: An outline of the importance of randomly placing participants into groups could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Decreasing bias by reducing the effect of different opinions (ensuring that individuals' pre-existing beliefs were evenly distributed across groups)

Subject: Biology
Content: Increasing validity by ensuring the only difference between groups was the information they received (minimising the impact of individual differences between participants)

Subject: Biology
Content: Increasing repeatability by ensuring groups were more likely to be representative of the population (increasing the diversity of each group in terms of age/gender/background).

Subject: Biology
Content: This was a challenging question and while many students used a range of terms from the key science skills, very few were able to apply these in the context of the investigation and the importance of random placement of participants.

Subject: Biology
Content: The investigation was valid because:

Subject: Biology
Content: A large sample size was used

Subject: Biology
Content: Responses were anonymous

Subject: Biology
Content: It measured what it aimed to measure (or a description of this) OR only one variable changed between groups (the information received between groups was the only independent variable)

Subject: Biology
Content: Group A acted as a control/comparison for Groups B and C

Subject: Biology
Content: The same information was given to all participants in the same group.

Subject: Biology
Content: 'Participants were randomly placed into groups' was not an acceptable response, as outlined in the stem of the question.

Subject: Biology
Content: OR

Subject: Biology
Content: The investigation was not valid because:

Subject: Biology
Content: The participants were from a limited demographic (linked to school / community / social media)

Subject: Biology
Content: It did not measure what it aimed to measure (or description of this) OR more than one variable was changed between groups (more than one independent variable)

Subject: Biology
Content: There was no control group of participants not receiving any information on vaccination

Subject: Biology
Content: Previous education/literacy levels of individuals or previous knowledge/education about vaccinations was not accounted for

Subject: Biology
Content: The data collected was subjective/qualitative or the online nature of responses was difficult to verify.

Subject: Biology
Content: Students could also identify the investigation as somewhat valid and provide any two relevant points from either list above. Students needed to comment on the validity of the results within their response to be awarded maximum marks.

Subject: Biology
Content: It was evident that many students did not have a strong grasp of the specific meanings of each of the data and measurement terms in the study design, such as 'accuracy', 'repeatability', 'validity' and 'precision', which were often used in incorrect contexts. Students should be provided with opportunities throughout the course to investigate and apply the key science skills to a range of scientific investigation methodologies as well as a range of biological contexts and scenarios.

Subject: Biology
Content: Section A: Section A

Subject: Biology
Content: The table below indicates the percentage of students who chose each option. Grey shading indicates the correct answer.

Subject: Biology
Content: Section B: Section B

Subject: Biology
Content: The diagram should be replicated with an indication that either introns had been removed OR exons spliced together, as shown in the sample answer below:

Subject: Biology
Content: Two additional modifications that could have been drawn and labelled included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Methyl/modified guanine cap

Subject: Biology
Content: Poly-A tail

Subject: Biology
Content: Alternative splicing (or a specific example such as intron retention or exon juggling).

Subject: Biology
Content: The thin lines connecting exons 1 and 2, and exons 2 and 3 in the original diagram were introns. Students were required to recognise that these non-protein coding regions are removed as a result of mRNA processing (post-transcription modification).

Subject: Biology
Content: Students were required to recognise that the modified guanine cap (methyl cap) and the poly-A tail should be added to opposite ends of the final mRNA strand. However, they were not required to recall that these are added to the 5' and 3' end, respectively.

Subject: Biology
Content: Students are encouraged to write in blue or black pen, even when drawing diagrams, to ensure answers scan clearly.

Subject: Biology
Content: In Step 4, DNA ligase joins the phosphodiester bonds between the human insulin gene A or B and their respective plasmid.

Subject: Biology
Content: In Step 8, amino acid chains A and B are combined to produce a functional insulin protein or quaternary structure.

Subject: Biology
Content: Students commonly misunderstood that each of the insulin genes are inserted separately into their respective plasmid and are not inserted together into the same plasmid.

Subject: Biology
Content: Enzymes have an active site complementary to specific substrate(s), which bind to that active site. Enzymes lower the activation energy required to convert substrates into products.

Subject: Biology
Content: As the question required students to explain how enzymes catalyse biochemical reactions, marks were not awarded for only stating that enzymes catalyse or speed up reactions.

Subject: Biology
Content: Students were required to make reference to both timeframes referred to in the question, recognising that between 0 and 20 minutes, trp was present in the cell and therefore enzyme activity was low as represented by the graph. After 60 minutes, trp was absent and therefore enzyme activity was steadily high as represented by the graph.

Subject: Biology
Content: Responses could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Between 0 and 20 minutes when trp is present:

Subject: Biology
Content: Repression and/or attenuation are occurring

Subject: Biology
Content: The rate of transcription is low because the trp repressor periodically detaches from the operator

Subject: Biology
Content: After 60 minutes when trp is absent and enzyme activity is constant:

Subject: Biology
Content: Repression and/or attenuation are not occurring

Subject: Biology
Content: Attenuation prevents more enzymes from being synthesised

Subject: Biology
Content: Enzymes already produced for trp synthesis are saturated or other limiting factors were present.

Subject: Biology
Content: Repression and attenuation work together to regulate the production of enzymes:

Subject: Biology
Content: When trp levels are high

Subject: Biology
Content: To prevent transcription and/or translation

Subject: Biology
Content: To prevent trp being synthesised

Subject: Biology
Content: Through attenuation occurring when repression fails.

Subject: Biology
Content: In many cases, students provided detailed knowledge of the mechanisms of repression and attenuation in both scenarios where trp was present and absent. However, accurate knowledge of these regulation mechanisms is required for the responses to be awarded full marks. Common mistakes included stating the repressor binds to the promoter or RNA polymerase was not able to translate genes, or confusing the terminator and anti-terminator hairpin loop.

Subject: Biology
Content: Students are also reminded to read the axis labels carefully. In this question, students often confused the y-axis as representing trp concentration as opposed to enzyme activity.

Subject: Biology
Content: Answering in dot points is acceptable and can help students to ensure they are addressing all parts of a question. Students should use the number of marks as an indication of the level of detail required in their response.

Subject: Biology
Content: Examples of limitations for the model simulation could have included that the simulation:

Subject: Biology
Content: Is overly simplified

Subject: Biology
Content: Does not account for what occurs in real time or in all prokaryotes

Subject: Biology
Content: Assumes ideal conditions or does not consider other factors that may have changed, such as temperature or pH

Subject: Biology
Content: Represents a general trend that excludes outliers

Subject: Biology
Content: Does not represent the results observed in the two sets of experimental data or enzyme activity above 1.0 (which is seen in the experimental data)

Subject: Biology
Content: Only accounted for when trp concentration was present or absent, rather than when this concentration would vary.

Subject: Biology
Content: This question was commonly misinterpreted by students who provided limitations of the two sets of experimental data (shown by triangles and squares) as opposed to the limitations of the model simulation.

Subject: Biology
Content: Example of a high-scoring student response:
Example: The model was overly simplified and did not replicate real world random variations in trp levels in the cell.

Subject: Biology
Content: In this response, students were required to identify a consequence for the bacteria now containing a codon for trp (as opposed to an additional stop codon) and justify their response. Students needed to associate this different codon with an impact on protein formation, structure and/or function and a consequence for the bacteria as a result.

Subject: Biology
Content: Examples of impacts on protein formation, structure and/or function could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Polypeptide sequence is longer or contains additional trp amino acids

Subject: Biology
Content: Polypeptide chains will fold differently

Subject: Biology
Content: Different proteins/enzymes produced

Subject: Biology
Content: Previously produced proteins may no longer be functional.

Subject: Biology
Content: Examples of appropriate consequences, either positive or negative, for the bacteria could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Additional amino acids were required to be synthesised or obtained from the environment

Subject: Biology
Content: Attenuation (or mechanisms of this process) would now be required or tRNA exists carrying trp

Subject: Biology
Content: Additional energy was required by the cell

Subject: Biology
Content: Less chance of nonsense mutations occurring

Subject: Biology
Content: Increased or decreased bacterial survival.

Subject: Biology
Content: Example of a high-scoring student response:
Example: Previous genes with the UGG codon at the end would now code for a longer primary structure of the protein as the UGG codon now codes for trp, rather than signalling termination of translation.

Subject: Biology
Example: Changes in primary structure may alter proteins in these bacteria.

Subject: Biology
Example: Lack of functional proteins disadvantageous for survival of bacteria.

Subject: Biology
Content: Students were awarded 1 mark for every two boxes correct. No mark was awarded when students put a cross in both cell locations or both times of day for a specific plant type.

Subject: Biology
Content: With increasing temperature, C3 plants do not have any adaptations to reduce photorespiration or may close their stomata. Oxygen is more likely to bind with Rubisco as opposed to carbon dioxide.

Subject: Biology
Content: In their response, students needed to indicate that it is specifically Rubisco which fixes oxygen and carbon dioxide (not carbon), rather than just the plant/cell in general. Statements about denaturation were not awarded marks. Students should also recognise that if denaturation occurred at higher temperatures, it would cause a permanent irreversible alteration of Rubisco's active site, meaning neither oxygen nor carbon dioxide would bind successfully.

Subject: Biology
Content: Spelling is not penalised in written responses in Biology exams, unless the misspelled word is a different correct word (e.g. if students misspelled 'stoma' as 'stroma' in this question).

Subject: Biology
Content: Examples of how light could be controlled could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Plants placed at an equal distance from the light/lamp OR light intensity/wavelength measured or kept the same

Subject: Biology
Content: Timing how long plants were exposed to light

Subject: Biology
Content: Removing sources of ambient or additional light.

Subject: Biology
Content: Examples of how water could be controlled could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Measuring a set volume of water or watering plants at the same time of day

Subject: Biology
Content: Regulating humidity or soil moisture.

Subject: Biology
Content: In this question, responses were required to describe how the students could control both light and water for the plants under investigation. Simple statements such as 'providing the same amount of light' or 'controlling the amount of water' did not address how this was performed, and simply restated information provided in the stem of the question. Responses should avoid use of the term 'amount' and instead use more specific terminology, such as 'volume', when discussing water.

Subject: Biology
Content: Reasons why measuring the amount of glucose would not be appropriate for the students' experiment could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Difficult to measure glucose

Subject: Biology
Content: Glucose is not a product (output) of photorespiration

Subject: Biology
Content: Glucose may be consumed (input) for cellular respiration

Subject: Biology
Content: Glucose can be converted into starch/cellulose in plants or used in the formation of fruits/seeds

Subject: Biology
Content: Plants may need to be damaged to test for or obtain glucose.

Subject: Biology
Content: This question highlights the importance of students knowing the inputs and outputs of photosynthesis and cellular respiration. Glucose is not an input to photosynthesis or photorespiration. If students referenced respiration using glucose, they must be aware that the term 'respiration' does not allow enough distinction to know if they were referring to photorespiration or cellular respiration in this question.

Subject: Biology
Content: Explanation of how editing of the OsHXK1 gene in rice could result in an increased crop yield could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: More light energy absorbed

Subject: Biology
Content: Increased rate of photosynthesis

Subject: Biology
Content: Greater production of glucose.

Subject: Biology
Content: Some responses simply restated that chlorophyll levels in the leaves were increased, rather than connecting increased chlorophyll levels to the ability of the leaves to absorb more light energy or to carry out more photosynthesis. These responses were not awarded a mark. Other responses about increased growth rate were also not awarded a mark, as they needed to be connected to how this would occur (e.g. by producing more glucose).

Subject: Biology
Content: Roles of neutrophils in an immune response to Neisseria meningitidis could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Migration to the site of infection

Subject: Biology
Content: Release of cytokines to attract other immune cells

Subject: Biology
Content: Phagocytosis of bacterium

Subject: Biology
Content: Release of toxins/defensins that are toxic to bacterium.

Subject: Biology
Content:
Contrasts between how the adaptive immune system response to an extracellular pathogen, like 
N. meningitidis, and an intracellular pathogen, like the influenza virus, could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: The type of immunity involved in each response differs: humoral immunity is involved in a response to an extracellular pathogen, whereas cell-mediated immunity is involved in a response to an intracellular pathogen

Subject: Biology
Content: The type of cells involved in each response differs: plasma B cells respond to extracellular pathogens, while cytotoxic T cells respond to intracellular pathogens

Subject: Biology
Content: The molecules and mechanisms involved in targeting each type of pathogen are different: antibodies agglutinate/neutralise/opsonise extracellular pathogens, whilst cytotoxic granules (perforin/protease) induce death of cells infected by intracellular pathogens

Subject: Biology
Content: The type of memory cells involved in each response is different: B memory cells are produced in response to extracellular pathogens, whereas T memory cells are produced in response to intracellular pathogens.

Subject: Biology
Content: Example of a high-scoring student response:
Example: Immune system utilises the humoral response to respond to extracellular pathogens whereas the cell-mediated response responds to intracellular pathogens.

Subject: Biology
Example: Humoral response results in the production of plasma cells to produce antibodies whereas the cell-mediated response produces cytotoxic T cells.

Subject: Biology
Example: Antibodies make it easier for the immune system to recognise and destroy pathogens via opsonisation whereas cytotoxic T cells induce apoptosis in virally infected cells.

Subject: Biology
Example: Cell-mediated response produces T memory cells whereas humoral response produces B memory cells.

Subject: Biology
Content: It was evident that many students did not understand how the adaptive immune response differed towards extracellular versus intracellular pathogens. Some students confused extracellular pathogens with pathogens that had not yet entered the body and incorrectly made contrasts between first, second and third lines of defence.

Subject: Biology
Content: Some students included similarities between the two responses. Students need to be familiar with the various command terms that appear in VCE Biology examinations; 'contrast' requires a student to outline differences, not similarities. Refer to the VCAA Glossary of command terms for more detail.

Subject: Biology
Content: Where available, students are advised to write in the empty space underneath a question, such as the space on p. 31 of the exam booklet below the prescribed lines, rather than continuing their answer on the 'Extra space for responses' pages at the back of the exam paper. This extra space at the back of the exam booklet should only be used where there is insufficient space to finish a response directly under the question.

Subject: Biology
Content: The correct answer was natural passive immunity:

Subject: Biology
Content: Passive because babies receive antibodies OR do not produce their own antibodies and/or memory cells

Subject: Biology
Content: Natural because these antibodies are provided from the mother (through the placenta/breastmilk) OR the baby obtained the antibodies through no further medical intervention.

Subject: Biology
Content: Students must ensure they understand that active and passive are different strategies and contradict each other. Likewise for natural and artificial/induced immunity.

Subject: Biology
Content: Reasons why a booster vaccine is advised if the mother became pregnant again could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Antibodies and/or memory cells decline over time

Subject: Biology
Content: Faster and/or larger antibody and/or memory cell production is required

Subject: Biology
Content: To ensure the baby receives sufficient antibodies

Subject: Biology
Content: To protect the baby/mother from RSV.

Subject: Biology
Content: Responses often incorrectly discussed memory cells being passed down from mother to child, which is incorrect. Additionally, many students did not make reference to either the baby or the mother in their response, instead providing pre-planned, generic responses about booster vaccines.

Subject: Biology
Content: Responses referring to antigenic drift were not awarded marks, as this may change the RSV antigens, rendering the booster vaccine ineffective. A new vaccine would be required.

Subject: Biology
Content: The economic benefit from the vaccination of pregnant women is that the relevant stakeholder either saves money (e.g. hospital, government, society) or makes money (e.g. pharmaceutical companies).

Subject: Biology
Content: Examples of explanations that could lead to economic benefit could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Reduced hospitalisations or emergency care or paediatric treatment

Subject: Biology
Content: Cheaper to vaccinate compared to treating preventable diseases

Subject: Biology
Content: Lowered risk of RSV or other infections/illness

Subject: Biology
Content: Reduced strain on government-funded healthcare programs or reduced burden on public health system

Subject: Biology
Content: Increased herd immunity preventing community spread of RSV

Subject: Biology
Content: Reduced maternal sick leave or less carer/partner absences from workplaces

Subject: Biology
Content: Improved long-term child health or reduction in child health/education support later in life.

Subject: Biology
Content: Generic responses such as 'children survived so they could contribute to the economy' were not accepted as a valid economic benefit. Many responses referred to saving costs by vaccinating two individuals with the one vaccine. Whilst this is true prior to birth, it was not awarded marks when the responses continued on to state that the child would then not require vaccination after being born, as this is biologically incorrect.

Subject: Biology
Content: For this type of question, students are encouraged to apply their knowledge and skills of ethical understanding (see page 12 of the study design). Specifically, students should be able to apply the VCE Biology Units 1-4 key science skill regarding '... the influence of social, economic, legal and political factors relevant to the selected issue', including how these factors may affect decision-making and consequences of these decisions.

Subject: Biology
Content: Explanations of how monoclonal antibodies work could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Binding to (RSV) antigen (not binding to pathogen/protein)

Subject: Biology
Content: Agglutination of virus

Subject: Biology
Content: Neutralisation of virus or prevention of virus spread

Subject: Biology
Content: Opsonisation or attraction of phagocytes to RSV

Subject: Biology
Content: Activation of complement proteins

Subject: Biology
Content: Activation of natural killer or cytotoxic T cells (which could occur through bispecific monoclonal antibodies, mAbs)

Subject: Biology
Content: Delivery of drugs/treatment directly to pathogen-infected cells (conjugated mAbs)

Subject: Biology
Content: Reduction of symptoms/number of RSV/number of infected cells.

Subject: Biology
Content: This question was challenging for students as it required them to apply their knowledge of the use of mAbs to an immune response against a pathogen such as RSV, rather than demonstrate their understanding in the more familiar contexts of the use of mAbs in the treatment of cancer and autoimmune diseases. The question required students to recognise that mAbs can function like any other antibody. Therefore, two suitable actions of antibodies were required.

Subject: Biology
Content: There were misconceptions by some students that antibodies kill pathogens or attach to antigens on pathogen-infected cells, whereas they actually attach to antigens of extracellular pathogens and trigger other responses to occur to eliminate the pathogen. Responses outlining how mAbs were produced were not awarded marks.

Subject: Biology
Content: Example of a high-scoring student response:
Example: Monoclonal antibodies have complementary variable regions to antigens on the RSV virus.

Subject: Biology
Example: Thus they can bind to viruses and mark them for phagocytosis, or clump them together to immobilise the pathogen, enhancing the speed and strength of the immune response especially for infants without fully developed adaptive immune systems, thus reducing the severity of symptoms.

Subject: Biology
Content: Aside from administering a vaccination (and the herd immunity that arises from this) or monoclonal antibody, ways to reduce the spread of RSV, with suitable justifications, could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Students needed to think carefully about their choice of strategy. For example, it would not be appropriate or ethical to isolate or quarantine the child from the mother. Some students identified an action and then justified this by simply stating 'reduces the spread' - such a response was simply restating the stem of the question instead of providing a justification and was not awarded a mark.

Subject: Biology
Content: Students needed to use the context provided, remembering that information at the beginning of Question 6 still applies to part e.

Subject: Biology
Content: The founder effect:

Subject: Biology
Content: Occurs when a small group of individuals establishes a new population with reduced genetic variation compared to the original population.

Subject: Biology
Content: The scientists are correct because:

Subject: Biology
Content: Only a single colony of Asian honey bees were introduced to Australia

Subject: Biology
Content: Only the genetic material of the queen and the sperm she had stored from her native environment were introduced to the new colony.

Subject: Biology
Content: Many responses did not make reference to genetic change, as was required by the question. Some students wrote about a smaller/unrepresentative population being produced, without explaining how this occurred, or without linking it to a smaller gene pool or unrepresentative allele frequencies. Some responses incorrectly described the bottleneck effect instead of the founder effect.

Subject: Biology
Content: The process responsible for the DNA differences is mutations.

Subject: Biology
Content: Explanations of how this process contributed to the successful expansion of the colonies could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: New alleles arose, increasing genetic diversity

Subject: Biology
Content: Individual bees with alleles that resulted in traits which increased their chances of survival were selected for

Subject: Biology
Content: Over time, this led to an increased proportion of individual bees with favourable alleles.

Subject: Biology
Content: Example of a high-scoring student response:
Example: Mutations.

Subject: Biology
Example: Mutations cause the formation of new alleles in the honeybee genome by altering the base sequence of DNA.

Subject: Biology
Example: Some of these alleles are highly beneficial, providing a selective advantage to individuals that have them, causing those with the alleles to have an increased likelihood of survival and reproduction, passing on favourable alleles to offspring, over generations producing entire colonies with the advantageous alleles which aids in successful expansion.

Subject: Biology
Content: Many responses did not directly answer the 'identify the process responsible for these DNA differences' part of the question. If they did, natural selection or genetic drift were common incorrect answers. These would change the frequency of alleles rather than actually producing the DNA differences that led to the new alleles.

Subject: Biology
Content: Explanations of potential genetic change in the native bee population could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: The genetic diversity in the native bee population may decline as alleles may be lost

Subject: Biology
Content: The native bee population may reduce in numbers, reducing its gene pool

Subject: Biology
Content: Individual native bees that cannot compete with the Asian honey bees are selected against and do not survive (or vice versa)

Subject: Biology
Content: These native bees do not reproduce, so less advantageous alleles are not passed on and decrease in frequency.

Subject: Biology
Content: Example of a high-scoring student response:
Example: Native bees may see a reduction in genetic diversity as only those bees able to survive and compete with Asian bees (selection pressure) for food and colony space will be able to reproduce and pass on these traits.

Subject: Biology
Example: Hence some alleles may see a decrease in frequency or be removed altogether as only advantageous traits increase in allele frequency with disadvantageous traits (worse food collection etc.) reduce in frequency or are erased from the gene pool altogether hence decreasing genetic diversity.

Subject: Biology
Content: Responses should avoid Lamarckian statements, such as suggesting the native bees adapted in order to survive competition from Asian honey bee species. Students should understand that genetic variants must be present for the species or population to survive threats from other species.

Subject: Biology
Content: Students are encouraged to relate their answers to the context of the question, rather than simply regurgitating pre-planned responses.

Subject: Biology
Content: Reasons why tadpoles were chosen for this experiment could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Tadpoles are laid in large groups, making it easier to obtain a large sample size for the experiment

Subject: Biology
Content: Tadpoles have transparent skin, meaning that light could easily pass through and be absorbed by the cyanobacteria

Subject: Biology
Content: Tadpoles have gills and live in water, therefore they can absorb dissolved oxygen

Subject: Biology
Content: Tadpoles are small animals, so they are easy/cheap to look after

Subject: Biology
Content: Tadpoles have a fast growth/reproduction rate, therefore the time to collect results is short

Subject: Biology
Content: Use of tadpoles received ethical approval as they are less complex animals.

Subject: Biology
Content: Lower-scoring responses simply listed information from the article, without proposing a connection between this information and why tadpoles were chosen for this experiment.

Subject: Biology
Content: The molecules that photosynthetic cyanobacteria would require to produce oxygen are:

Subject: Biology
Content: Water

Subject: Biology
Content: Chlorophyll

Subject: Biology
Content: Coenzymes/NADP/ADP + Pi.

Subject: Biology
Content: Students need to be familiar with the inputs and outputs of the light-dependent and light-independent stages of photosynthesis. Some responses incorrectly identified carbon dioxide and/or glucose, which are inputs/outputs of the light-independent stage and not directly involved in the production of oxygen. Light was also not awarded a mark, as while it is required to produce oxygen, it is not a molecule.

Subject: Biology
Content: Role of each of the molecules named in part b.i. in the production of oxygen:

Subject: Biology
Content: Water is split to form oxygen and load coenzymes/NADP/ADP + Pi

Subject: Biology
Content: Chlorophyll captures light energy to facilitate splitting of water and loading of coenzymes/NADP/ADP + Pi

Subject: Biology
Content: Coenzymes/NADP/ADP + Pi assist enzymes to function by transferring electrons/energy/hydrogen ions between reactions.

Subject: Biology
Content: A mark was awarded for this question if the student incorrectly identified light as a molecule in part b.i. (with no mark awarded for part b.i.) but then provided a correct description of the role of light energy in the splitting of water to produce oxygen in part b.ii.

Subject: Biology
Content: Explanations of why the tadpoles' brain activity stopped could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Tadpoles could not carry out aerobic respiration as oxygen is required as an input

Subject: Biology
Content: Tadpoles carried out anaerobic respiration, which produces less ATP than aerobic respiration

Subject: Biology
Content: Cells were unable to produce sufficient ATP/energy.

Subject: Biology
Content: Many students identified that the dark, hypoxic environment meant photosynthesis was not occurring and therefore oxygen was not being produced, however they were unable to connect this to aerobic/anaerobic respiration and how it would affect the tadpole's brain activity. Some responses stated that low oxygen led to denaturation of enzymes or death of cells, however this was incorrect as brain activity was able to be restarted.

Subject: Biology
Content: Reasons for the delay in the restart of the tadpoles' brain activity could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: It takes time for oxygen to be produced

Subject: Biology
Content: It takes time for photosynthesis to occur

Subject: Biology
Content: It takes time for oxygen to be used

Subject: Biology
Content: It takes time for aerobic/cellular respiration to occur

Subject: Biology
Content: It takes time for ATP to be produced

Subject: Biology
Content: Oxygen/ATP is required for brain activity.

Subject: Biology
Content: Example of a high-scoring student response:
Example: After cyanobacteria were exposed to light, time was taken for the photolysis of water to occur and oxygen (O2) levels to reach sufficient amounts for cellular respiration to occur (which is also time consuming and slow) in order to produce sufficient ATP for the brain to start functioning again.

Subject: Biology
Content: Students needed to refer to a biochemical pathway in their response, connecting the pathway to the production of oxygen or ATP. Low-scoring responses simply identified a biochemical pathway or outlined steps in photosynthesis or cellular respiration without connecting it to the tadpoles' brain activity.

Subject: Biology
Content: Events that occur along the electron transport chain could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Coenzymes/NADH/FADH2 transfer/unload electrons/energy/hydrogen ions

Subject: Biology
Content: Water is formed

Subject: Biology
Content: Oxygen is used as an input

Subject: Biology
Content: 26 or 28 ATP molecules are produced.

Subject: Biology
Content: As outlined in the study design, students need to be familiar with the inputs and outputs of the various stages of cellular respiration, including ATP yield (details of biochemical pathway mechanisms are not required).

Subject: Biology
Content: Justifications using information from the article to support agreement with Student X could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Beneficence relates to maximising benefits and reducing harm/risk

Subject: Biology
Content: Benefit is being maximised as the research could save human lives in future by increasing oxygen levels in medical emergencies

Subject: Biology
Content: Harm is being minimised as while tadpole brain activity was stopped, it was restarted again.

Subject: Biology
Content: Example of a high-scoring student response:
Example: Student X.

Subject: Biology
Example: Beneficence involves maximising positive outcomes (or ensuring if harm is inevitable, that it is outweighed).

Subject: Biology
Example: Positive outcomes such as the potential of increasing oxygen levels in humans during medical emergencies were maximised, saving lives, rendering it ethical in the long term despite minimal harm to tadpole.

Subject: Biology
Content: OR

Subject: Biology
Content: Justifications using information from the article to support agreement with Student Y could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Non-maleficence relates to avoiding harm OR ensuring harm is not disproportionate to benefits

Subject: Biology
Content: Benefits are disproportionate as the potential positive outcome of improving treatment for humans during medical emergencies does not outweigh the harm being caused to the tadpoles

Subject: Biology
Content: Harm is not being minimised as tadpoles are being harmed by having cyanobacteria injected into their hearts.

Subject: Biology
Content: Example of a high-scoring student response:
Example: I agree with student Y. Treating tadpoles as test subjects and intentionally placing them in hypoxic conditions may cause stress and pain. This violates non-maleficence (the minimisation of preventable harm) as the tadpoles are intentionally placed in distress from hypoxic conditions.

Subject: Biology
Content: Some responses included justifications that did not match the student (X or Y) they were agreeing with. Students need to be able to demonstrate and apply ethical understanding using the ethical concepts outlined on pages 15 and 16 of the study design.

Subject: Biology
Content: Examples of molecular homology comparisons could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Nucleic acid (nucleotides, DNA, RNA) sequences

Subject: Biology
Content: Amino acid sequences.

Subject: Biology
Content: A description of how molecular homology can be interpreted could be:

Subject: Biology
Content: The more similar these sequences are between two populations or the less time for mutations to occur between them, the more closely related they are (or vice versa).

Subject: Biology
Content: As this question was about different populations of woodpecker finches rather than different species, students should be careful about using standard responses that discuss how molecular homology can be used to compare species, as opposed to populations.

Subject: Biology
Content: The type of speciation could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Allopatric

Subject: Biology
Content: Geographic isolation

Subject: Biology
Content: Finches on San Cristobal may not be able to fly the distance to other islands.

Subject: Biology
Content: Explanations of how speciation occurred could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: No gene flow/interbreeding between populations

Subject: Biology
Content: Different mutations accumulating in each population

Subject: Biology
Content: Each population experiencing different selection pressures and certain individuals having a selective advantage.

Subject: Biology
Content: Students did not need to use the term 'allopatric speciation' in their response; instead they could indicate their understanding of the type of speciation by referring to the population as geographically isolated. As students were required to explain the type of speciation that occurred, they needed to state more than just 'different selection pressures were acting'. Making reference to a survival/selective/reproductive advantage or individuals containing certain alleles/phenotypes/traits conferring an advantage was important.

Subject: Biology
Content: This was not sympatric speciation as there was no evidence of different mating times of the finches or other temporal isolations. and the woodpecker finches on San Cristobal island were not living in the same location as the other woodpecker finch populations.

Subject: Biology
Content: Evidence that would support Conclusion 1 needed to relate to a feature of the footprints that would demonstrate bipedalism. This could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Non-opposable big toe

Subject: Biology
Content: Arched foot

Subject: Biology
Content: More pronounced heel bone.

Subject: Biology
Content: Evidence that would support Conclusion 2 needed to relate to a feature that differs between different bipedal footprints. This could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: Angle of the big toe compared to other toes is different

Subject: Biology
Content: Different size of arch in foot

Subject: Biology
Content: Different distribution of weight from heel to toe.

Subject: Biology
Content: For Conclusion 2, students needed to identify a structural difference between the footprints rather than simply stating that the footprints would be different or that they would be different sizes, as this could indicate the footprints were from the same species but of different ages (child/adult size) rather than from different species.

Subject: Biology
Content: Reasons for the difference in the interbreeding conclusions made, with a suitable justification using information from the table, could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: There were different numbers of genomes studied, as Study 1 involved 7 genomes while Study 2 involved 334 genomes

Subject: Biology
Content: The individuals studied were from different time periods, as Study 1 involved individuals dated 45 000 years ago while Study 2 involved individuals dated from both 45 000 to 2200 years ago and from present day

Subject: Biology
Content: The two studies had different levels of accuracy, as Study 2 had a larger sample size than Study 1 and/or Study 2 involved both ancient and present-day individuals whereas Study 1 only involved ancient individuals

Subject: Biology
Content: Researchers can interpret data differently as demonstrated by the different ranges of interbreeding found in the two conclusions, with Study 1 concluding that the range of interbreeding was from 49 000 years ago to 45 000 years ago while Study 2 concluded that the range of interbreeding was from 50 500 years ago to 43 500 years ago.

Subject: Biology
Content: Explanations for the change in the percentage of Neanderthal DNA found in ancient human individuals compared to present-day individuals could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: There has been a decrease in the percentage of Neanderthal DNA in the genomes of present-day humans

Subject: Biology
Content: More time has passed since Homo sapiens and Homo neanderthalensis shared a common ancestor OR more time for mutations to accumulate in the DNA of present-day individuals compared to ancient humans

Subject: Biology
Content: In present-day individuals there has been more time for interbreeding between H. sapiens OR between H. sapiens and other species of the genus Homo

Subject: Biology
Content: H. sapiens and H. neanderthalensis can no longer interbreed as H. neanderthalensis is extinct

Subject: Biology
Content: Present-day individuals may not be descended from ancestors with high levels of Neanderthal DNA

Subject: Biology
Content: Over time, different selection pressures have favoured different alleles, resulting in alleles that were prominent in ancient humans being lost.

Subject: Biology
Content: When discussing interbreeding, students needed to provide specific details, such as which species were interbreeding, when they were interbreeding or to what extent they were likely to interbreed.

Subject: Biology
Content: Benefits of using mtDNA to help determine the pathways hominin species may have taken could have included:

Subject: Biology
Content: MtDNA is passed down the maternal line or mtDNA is not subject to recombination

Subject: Biology
Content: MtDNA has a known/high mutation rate

Subject: Biology
Content: MtDNA's only source of variation is mutation

Subject: Biology
Content: MtDNA is more abundant or has a higher copy number than nuclear DNA.

Subject: Biology
Content: Responses that described how mtDNA can determine migratory pathways rather than outlining the benefits of using mtDNA were not awarded marks.
